1. A 52-year-old male presents with a 6-month history of fluctuating blood pressure readings, often spiking above 180/110 mmHg despite adherence to multiple antihypertensive medications. He reports intermittent headaches, palpitations, and episodes of excessive sweating, particularly during stressful situations. His medical history includes a traumatic spinal cord injury from a motor vehicle accident five years ago, resulting in partial paralysis below the T6 level. Physical exam reveals preserved upper limb strength but diminished sensation and reflexes in the lower limbs. Laboratory evaluations and renal function tests are within normal limits, and secondary causes of hypertension such as renal artery stenosis and pheochromocytoma have been excluded. Ambulatory blood pressure monitoring shows significant variability with sudden surges in systolic pressure. Autonomic testing demonstrates exaggerated sympathetic responses below the level of the lesion. The clinical picture suggests neurogenic hypertension secondary to dysregulated autonomic control following spinal cord injury.
